oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Willie Nelson Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Willie Nelson (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Willie Nelson; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Willie Nelson and Biff Collie discuss the various places Nelson lived prior to Nashville -- (00:43) Collie invites Nelson to discuss "Family Bible," and Nelson reveals that he sold the song to Claude Gray, Walter Breeland, and Paul Buskirk for fifty dollars -- (01:07) Nelson discusses how he partially sold "Night Life" to Breeland and Buskirk, and that, unlike "Family Bible," all of the "Night Life" royalties had reverted back to Nelson -- (01:38) Collie and Nelson reflect on how "Family Bible" was the first gospel song Nelson recorded, and Nelson tells that Jimmy Davis and George Jones were among the many that recorded "Family Bible" -- (02:03) Collie and Nelson reflect on how Nelson originally went to Tootsies when he arrived in Nashville -- (02:25) Nelson reveals how he first met Hank Cochran at Tooties, and Nelson tells that Cochran introduced Nelson to his first writing contract -- (03:19) Nelson discusses meeting Harlan Howard, Roger Miller, Jim Reeves, and Don Rowlands in Nashville, and Collie and Nelson reflect on what is called the 'romantic period of Nashville' -- (04:50) Collie introduces the idea that Nelson's music was so popular that it could boost anyone's career -- (05:37) Nelson recalls the time where he was accepted as a song writer; Collie and Nelson discuss the opportunities Liberty Records and RCA Records opened for Nelson -- (06:34) Collie reveals he tells people that he does not look for a specific type of song as long as it is a 'hit' song -- (07:06) Nelson and Collie discuss how Nelson recorded Always on My Mind in Nashville, but Nelson would be willing to record anywhere -- (07:50) Collie introduces the popularity of Nelson and Collie recalls calling Nelson the first 'jazz-country' singer in the 1960's -- (09:03) Nelson attributes his unique style to his boredom from performing live consistently -- (09:40) Collie and Nelson discuss whether or not Nelson had ever performed 'scat music' -- (10:04) Collie addresses the public opinion of why Nelson left Nashville, and Nelson attributes it to getting closer to work -- (11:45) Collie and Nelson discuss the benefit Nelson got from working in Texas -- (12:50) Collie and Nelson reflect on the career of Adolph Hofner, and Nelson says Ray Charles is the most important country artist -- (14:06) Nelson says the other most influential country artist is Hank Williams because of his limited fandom -- (14:40) Country music is linked to blues music and Nelson says, "There's only two songs ever written, 'the Star Spangled Banner' and the blues" -- (15:04) Nelson links every genre to the blues and Collie has Nelson reflect on "Star Dust" -- (15:48) Nelson compares "Funny How Time Slips Away" and "I Got to Get Drunk" being reflections of an artist's mood -- (16:14) Collie has Nelson reflect on the turning point of his career -- (16:30) Collie and Nelson discuss how the fourth of July picnics had an effect on Nelson's career, and Nelson tells how the Armadillo Club was a safe haven for the youthful residents -- (19:33) Collie and Nelson joke about Nelson's image change being a symbol of rebellion -- (20:26) Collie recalls the tale that if Jesus were to return today he would be stoned to death -- (20:48) Nelson explains his hesitation to perform on television -- (21:34) Nelson discusses how he does not believe television to be the correct move for his career -- (21:45) Nelson reflects on how he is doing a couple shows to promote his new album -- (22:05) Nelson says that he went on Johnny Carson's show because he was impressed -- (22:23) Collie reflects on the grand gesture Carson made and Nelson expresses his wishes to record with George Burns -- (22:59) Collie and Nelson discuss how Nelson met Waylon Jennings in Texas, and Nelson reflects on how they recorded their first duet album together -- (24:37) Nelson explains how it was necessary, when he originally recorded with Jennings, to do so without record management interference -- (25:30) Collie and Nelson discuss how Robert Redford originally introduced Nelson to movie work with Electric Horseman -- (27:41) Nelson describes his thoughts on being asked to perform on Electric Horseman -- (28:13) Collie and Nelson discuss the transition from musician to actor -- (28:40) Nelson reveals to Collie that Honeysuckle Rose was actually originally written for Hoyt Axton and not himself -- (29:18) Collie inquires about Nelson's excitement for the movie business, and Nelson explains the lack of security in the movie industry -- (30:23) Nelson expresses his joy from working in movies but emphasizes how he will not leave the music industry
